title: The rise of the Ottoman Empire - Mostafa Minawi

multiple-choice.question: Who established a small beylik in what is now Turkey in the late 13th century?
What was the primary factor that enabled the rapid rise of the Ottoman Empire?

options.label: C
options.text: A mixture of strategic political alliances and military conflicts

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the fierce military elite force composed of captured and converted Christian boys?

Who attacked the Ottoman Empire from the east in the first half of the 15th century?
Who conquered Constantinople in 1453?
What was the common Greek name for Constantinople?
What was the significance of the Ottoman Empire's expansion into the Balkans?

options.label: A
options.text: It marked the beginning of the Ottoman Empire's decline

options.label: B
options.text: It led to the capture of thousands of young Christian boys who were converted to Islam and trained as Janissaries

options.label: C
options.text: It resulted in the Ottoman Empire's isolation from the rest of Europe

options.label: D
options.text: It had no significant impact on the Ottoman Empire's growth

What was the approximate duration of the Ottoman Empire's existence?

title: Savitri and Satyavan: The legend of the princess who outwitted Death - Iseult Gillespie

multiple-choice.question: What was Princess Savitri's reputation like in the Madra Kingdom?

options.label: B
options.text: She was known for her intelligence and kindness.

multiple-choice.question: What motivated Princess Savitri to find a husband herself?

options.label: A
options.text: She was unhappy with her parents' choices.

options.label: B
options.text: She was impressed by the men who came to the palace.

options.label: C
options.text: She was unimpressed by the men who came to the palace and lost their nerve.

options.label: D
options.text: She wanted to marry a wealthy prince.

multiple-choice.question: What was Satyavan's situation when Princess Savitri met him?

options.label: C
options.text: He was working to support his family after his father was overthrown.

multiple-choice.question: What was the prophecy revealed by Narada about Satyavan?

options.label: A
options.text: He would live a long and happy life.

options.label: B
options.text: He would become a great king.

options.label: C
options.text: He had only a year to live.

options.label: D
options.text: He would marry a wealthy princess.

multiple-choice.question: How did Princess Savitri respond to the prophecy?

options.label: A
options.text: She decided to marry another man.

options.label: B
options.text: She accepted the prophecy and prepared for Satyavan's death.

options.label: C
options.text: She swore to never marry another and vowed to find a way to prolong Satyavan's life.

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of Princess Savitri's efforts to prolong Satyavan's life?

options.label: A
options.text: Satyavan lived a long and happy life.

options.label: B
options.text: Satyavan's life was prolonged, but he eventually died.

options.label: C
options.text: Satyavan's life was not prolonged, and he died on the predicted day.

options.label: D
options.text: Princess Savitri's efforts had no effect on Satyavan's life.

multiple-choice.question: Conceptual Question: What does Princess Savitri's story illustrate about the power of love and devotion?

options.label: A
options.text: That love and devotion can conquer even death.

options.label: B
options.text: That love and devotion are not enough to change fate.

options.label: C
options.text: That love and devotion are only important in romantic relationships.

options.label: D
options.text: That love and devotion are not important in life.

multiple-choice.question: Application Question: What lesson can be learned from Princess Savitri's persistence in following Yamraj and asking for wishes?

options.label: A
options.text: That one should always give up when faced with adversity.

options.label: B
options.text: That persistence and determination can lead to positive outcomes.

options.label: C
options.text: That one should always follow the rules and not question authority.

options.label: D
options.text: That wishes are always granted without effort.

multiple-choice.question: Analytical Question: What does the story suggest about the character of Yamraj, the God of Death?

options.label: A
options.text: That he is cruel and heartless.

options.label: B
options.text: That he is fair and just, but also has a softer side.

options.label: C
options.text: That he is only interested in collecting souls and does not care about human emotions.

options.label: D
options.text: That he is not a powerful god.

multiple-choice.question: Factual Question: What was the final wish granted to Princess Savitri by Yamraj?

options.label: C
options.text: To be the mother of many children.

options.label: D
options.text: To bring Satyavan back to life.

title: The life cycle of a cup of coffee - A.J. Jacobs

multiple-choice.question: Where were Coffea trees first domesticated?
What is the purpose of the wet mill in the coffee production process?

options.label: B
options.text: To separate the seeds from the fruit and sort them by density

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of Q-graders in the coffee production process?

options.label: C
options.text: To evaluate the coffee's taste, aroma, and mouthfeel to determine its quality

options.label: B
options.text: To separate the seeds from the fruit

options.label: C
options.text: To release oil within the seed, transforming the seeds into grindable, brewable beans

options.label: D

title: Do personality tests work? - Merve Emre

multiple-choice.question: Who developed the Myers-Briggs Type Indicator (MBTI) in 1942?

options.label: A
options.text: Katherine Cook Briggs and Carl Jung

options.label: B
options.text: Isabel Briggs Myers and Sigmund Freud

options.label: C
options.text: Katherine Cook Briggs and Isabel Briggs Myers

multiple-choice.question: What is a major problem with the way personality tests are constructed?

options.label: A
options.text: They are too long and time-consuming

options.label: B
options.text: They are based on different sets of metrics to define personality

options.label: C
options.text: They are only used by individuals, not by schools and companies

options.label: D
options.text: They are too expensive to administer

multiple-choice.question: Why is objective self-evaluation tricky in personality tests?

options.label: A
options.text: Because people tend to answer questions honestly

options.label: B
options.text: Because people subconsciously aim to please and show a bias toward answering in a favorable way

options.label: C
options.text: Because people are not interested in taking personality tests

options.label: D
options.text: Because people are not aware of their own personalities

multiple-choice.question: What is a limitation of the forced-choice questions used in personality tests like the MBTI?

options.label: A
options.text: They allow participants to choose multiple answers

options.label: B
options.text: They force participants to choose one answer, even if they value both options

options.label: C
options.text: They are only used in the Big Five personality test

options.label: D
options.text: They are only used in the Enneagram personality test

multiple-choice.question: What was the finding of a study on the consistency of Myers-Briggs test results?

options.label: A
options.text: Nearly all people who take the test a second time get assigned the same type

options.label: B
options.text: Nearly half of people who take the test a second time get assigned a different type

options.label: C
options.text: The test results are always consistent, regardless of when the test is taken

options.label: D
options.text: The test results are never consistent, regardless of when the test is taken

multiple-choice.question: How have the definitions of personality traits like introversion and extroversion changed over time?

options.label: A
options.text: They have remained the same since they were first defined

options.label: B
options.text: They have changed slightly, but still reflect the original definitions

options.label: C
options.text: They have changed significantly, with introversion originally meaning sticking to principles and extroversion meaning molding oneself to circumstance

options.label: D
options.text: They have been replaced by new definitions of personality traits

multiple-choice.question: What does research suggest about personality?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a stable, measurable feature of an individual

options.label: B
options.text: It is not a stable, measurable feature of an individual, and can shift during key periods

options.label: C
options.text: It is only shaped by upbringing and life experiences

options.label: D
options.text: It is only shaped by genetics and biology

multiple-choice.question: How are personality tests often used in schools and companies?

options.label: A
options.text: To advise students what to study and what jobs to pursue, and to decide who to hire and for what positions

options.label: B
options.text: To provide individual feedback and self-discovery

options.label: C
options.text: To predict how a person will perform in a specific role

options.label: D
options.text: To discourage people from considering certain paths

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential consequence of using personality tests to advise students and make hiring decisions?

options.label: A
options.text: People may be encouraged to pursue opportunities they are well-suited for

options.label: B
options.text: People may be deprived of opportunities they would excel at, or discouraged from considering certain paths

options.label: C
options.text: People may become more aware of their own personalities and strengths

options.label: D
options.text: People may become less aware of their own personalities and strengths

multiple-choice.question: Why should users of personality tests take the results with a grain of salt?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the tests are always accurate and reliable

options.label: B
options.text: Because the tests are only used for individual self-discovery

options.label: C
options.text: Because the tests have design flaws and limitations, and the results may not reflect real-life nuances

options.label: D
options.text: Because the tests are too expensive to administer

title: Climate change will displace millions. Here's how we prepare - Colette Pichon Battle

multiple-choice.question: What event led the speaker to first see the Louisiana flood maps?

options.label: B
options.text: A community meeting two years after Hurricane Katrina

options.label: C
options.text: A conversation with a friend from the United Houma Nation

multiple-choice.question: What is predicted to happen to over 180 million people by the end of the next century due to climate change?

options.label: A
options.text: They will lose their homes due to sea level rise

options.label: C
options.text: They will experience extreme weather conditions

options.label: D
options.text: They will have to adapt to a new economic system

multiple-choice.question: What term has been misused to identify people displaced by climate disaster, even if they don't cross international borders?
According to the speaker, what is the root cause of the climate crisis?

options.label: C
options.text: An economic system built for a few to extract value from the planet and its people

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's proposed solution to address the climate crisis?

options.label: A
options.text: Relying on technology to save us

options.label: B
options.text: Continuing the current economic system with minor adjustments

options.label: C
options.text: Restructuring social and economic systems to develop collective resilience and advance human liberty globally

options.label: D
options.text: Focusing solely on reducing CO2 emissions

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept of "climate gentrification" as described by the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: The process of rebuilding damaged homes with sustainable materials

options.label: B
options.text: The forced relocation of people away from the coast due to sea level rise

options.label: C
options.text: The pricing out of low-income communities from high ground areas as people move away from the coast

options.label: D
options.text: The influx of people moving to coastal areas despite the risks of climate change

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's vision for cities that can receive people displaced by climate migration?

options.label: A
options.text: Cities with strict border controls and limited resources

options.label: B
options.text: Cities with sprawling infrastructure and declining social services

options.label: C
options.text: Cities that provide housing, food, water, healthcare, and freedom from over-policing for everyone

options.label: D
options.text: Cities that prioritize economic growth over social justice

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is required to address the climate crisis and ensure collective resilience?

options.label: A
options.text: A focus on individual privilege and short-term gains

options.label: B
options.text: A commitment to standards of ecological equity, climate justice, and human rights

options.label: C
options.text: A reliance on technology and existing economic systems

options.label: D
options.text: A focus solely on reducing CO2 emissions

multiple-choice.question: What does the speaker mean by "reindigenizing ourselves"?

options.label: A
options.text: Returning to a primitive way of life

options.label: C
options.text: Learning to follow and respect the leadership and traditional knowledge of local places

options.label: D
options.text: Dismissing the importance of indigenous cultures

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's ultimate message and call to action?

options.label: A
options.text: We must accept the inevitable consequences of climate change and adapt to a new reality

options.label: B
options.text: We must prioritize individual interests and economic growth over collective well-being

options.label: C
options.text: We must work together to transform our social and economic systems, prioritize human rights and ecological equity, and ensure collective resilience

options.label: D
options.text: We must rely on technology to solve the climate crisis

title: 10 ways to have a better conversation - Celeste Headlee

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the primary reason why conversations often devolve into arguments?

options.label: A
options.text: People are too busy to listen to each other.

options.label: B
options.text: Technology has made it easier to communicate, but not necessarily to converse.

options.label: C
options.text: The world has become more polarized, with people becoming more entrenched in their views.

options.label: D
options.text: Conversational skills are no longer taught in schools.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the high school teacher who wrote an article in The Atlantic about the importance of teaching conversational skills?
What is the speaker's first rule for having better conversations?

options.label: D
options.text: Repeat back what you just heard

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the most important skill that you can develop in order to have better conversations?

options.label: D
options.text: Being able to summarize what the other person said

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the famous therapist who said that true listening requires setting aside one's own personal opinions?
According to the speaker, what is the problem with equating your own experiences with those of the person you are talking to?

options.label: A
options.text: It shows that you are empathetic and care about the other person's feelings.

options.label: B
options.text: It helps to build rapport and establish common ground.

options.label: C
options.text: It can come across as condescending and dismissive of the other person's experiences.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a way of avoiding talking about sensitive topics.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's advice for dealing with thoughts that come into your mind while you are listening to someone else?

options.label: A
options.text: Try to suppress them and focus on what the other person is saying.

options.label: B
options.text: Share them with the other person and see if they have any insights.

options.label: C
options.text: Let them go and don't worry about them.

options.label: D
options.text: Write them down so you can remember them later.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the benefit of using open-ended questions in conversations?

options.label: A
options.text: They allow you to control the conversation and steer it in the direction you want.

options.label: B
options.text: They help to build rapport and establish common ground.

options.label: C
options.text: They encourage the other person to share more of their thoughts and feelings.

options.label: D
options.text: They are a way of avoiding talking about sensitive topics.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's advice for dealing with situations where you don't know the answer to a question?

options.label: A
options.text: Try to bluff your way through and pretend you know what you're talking about.

options.label: B
options.text: Admit that you don't know and ask if the other person can help you understand.

options.label: C
options.text: Change the subject and try to steer the conversation in a different direction.

options.label: D
options.text: Get defensive and argue that you do know what you're talking about.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the key to being a good conversationalist?

options.label: A
options.text: Being able to talk about a wide range of topics.

options.label: B
options.text: Being able to listen actively and respond thoughtfully.

options.label: C
options.text: Being able to ask clever and insightful questions.

options.label: D
options.text: Being able to dominate the conversation and steer it in the direction you want.

title: Why is pneumonia so dangerous? - Eve Gaus and Vanessa Ruiz

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the alveoli in the lungs?

options.label: C
options.text: To produce mucus to trap invaders

options.text: A type of white blood cell that fights pathogens

options.label: B
options.text: A mechanism that traps invaders and carries them towards the mouth

options.label: C
options.text: A type of bacteria that causes pneumonia

options.label: D
options.text: A type of virus that causes pneumonia

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.text: Because there is no effective treatment for pneumonia

title: What if there were 1 trillion more trees? - Jean-François Bastin

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated age of the giant sequoia nicknamed General Sherman?
What process do plants use to consume atmospheric carbon?

options.label: A

title: Can you outsmart the fallacy that started a witch hunt? - Elizabeth Cox

multiple-choice.question: In what year did Senator Joseph McCarthy claim to have a list of 205 communists in the US who were influencing government policy?
What type of argument is being referred to when assuming a claim is true because it hasn't been proven false?
What is the rule of thumb mentioned in the transcript regarding claims and proof?

options.label: A
options.text: The burden of proof lies with the person denying the claim.

options.label: B
options.text: The burden of proof lies with the person making the claim.

options.label: D
options.text: Proof is not necessary in decision-making.

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of the senate subcommittee's investigation into Dorothy Kenyon?

options.label: A
options.text: She was found guilty of being a communist.

options.label: B
options.text: The charges against her were dismissed.

options.label: C
options.text: She was forced to resign from her position.

multiple-choice.question: What happened to Senator Joseph McCarthy in 1954?

options.label: A
options.text: He was re-elected to the senate.

options.label: B
options.text: He was formally disciplined by the senate.

options.label: C
options.text: He became the president of the United States.

multiple-choice.question: What is the consequence of assuming a claim is true because it hasn't been proven false?

options.label: A
options.text: It leads to a thorough investigation of the claim.

options.label: B
options.text: It ignores many other possibilities, such as the claim not being proven false yet.

options.label: C
options.text: It automatically makes the claim true.

multiple-choice.question: If someone makes a claim that contradicts an established consensus, what is their responsibility?

options.label: B
options.text: To provide evidence to support their claim.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between the burden of proof and claims that contradict an established consensus?

options.label: A
options.text: The burden of proof lies with the person making the claim, but only if it supports the consensus.

options.label: B
options.text: The burden of proof lies with the person making the claim, especially if it contradicts the consensus.

options.label: C
options.text: The burden of proof lies with the person denying the claim, especially if it contradicts the consensus.

options.label: D
options.text: There is no relationship between the burden of proof and claims that contradict an established consensus.

multiple-choice.question: How did the widespread anti-communist influence of Senator Joseph McCarthy affect people in the US?

options.label: A
options.text: Hundreds of people were elected to public office, and thousands gained jobs.

options.label: B
options.text: Hundreds of people were incarcerated, and thousands lost their jobs.

options.label: C
options.text: There was no impact on the lives of people in the US.

options.label: D
options.text: The influence was limited to the senate.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of evidence in supporting or refuting a claim?

options.label: A
options.text: Evidence is not necessary to support or refute a claim.

options.label: B
options.text: Evidence is only necessary to support a claim, not to refute it.

options.label: C
options.text: Evidence is necessary to both support and refute a claim.

options.label: D
options.text: Evidence is only necessary to refute a claim, not to support it.

title: Are all of your memories real? - Daniel L. Schacter

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the study where participants were told they had gotten lost in a shopping mall as children?

options.label: A
options.text: None of the participants recalled getting lost in a mall.

options.label: B
options.text: A quarter of the participants recalled getting lost in vivid detail.

options.label: C
options.text: Half of the participants recalled getting lost but with vague details.

options.label: D
options.text: All participants recalled getting lost but with varying levels of detail.

multiple-choice.question: What is one common way our memories diverge from what actually happened, as highlighted by the mall study?

options.label: A
options.text: We tend to forget important details over time.

options.label: B
options.text: We can incorporate information from outside sources into our personal recollections without realizing it.

options.label: C
options.text: We often recall events in reverse chronological order.

options.label: D
options.text: We usually remember traumatic events more accurately.

multiple-choice.question: What happened in the study where participants were shown a random collection of photographs, including images of a university campus they had never visited?

options.label: A
options.text: A majority of participants correctly identified the campus as unfamiliar.

options.label: B
options.text: A majority of participants said they had probably or definitely visited the campus in the past.

options.label: C
options.text: Participants showed no interest in visiting the campus after seeing the images.

options.label: D
options.text: Participants were unable to recall any details about the campus.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of how our current opinions, feelings, and experiences can bias our memories of how we felt in the past?

options.label: A
options.text: Participants in a study who changed their views on marijuana legalization tended to recall their original views accurately.

options.label: B
options.text: Participants in a study who changed their views on marijuana legalization tended to recall their original views as being more extreme.

options.label: C
options.text: Participants in a study who changed their views on marijuana legalization tended to recall their original views as being in line with their current views.

options.label: D
options.text: Participants in a study who changed their views on marijuana legalization tended to recall their original views as being unrelated to their current views.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the study where researchers gave two groups of participants background information on a historical war and asked them to rate the likelihood that each side would win?

options.label: A
options.text: The group that knew the actual outcome of the war rated the winning side as less likely to win.

options.label: B
options.text: The group that knew the actual outcome of the war rated the winning side as more likely to win.

options.label: C
options.text: Both groups rated the winning side as equally likely to win.

options.label: D
options.text: The group that did not know the actual outcome of the war rated the winning side as more likely to win.

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential real-world impact of the fallibility of memory in a courtroom setting?

options.label: A
options.text: Jurors may be more likely to consider inadmissible evidence.

options.label: B
options.text: Jurors may be less likely to consider inadmissible evidence.

options.label: C
options.text: Judges may be more likely to rule in favor of the prosecution.

options.label: D
options.text: Judges may be less likely to rule in favor of the defense.

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential real-world impact of the fallibility of memory in a medical setting?

options.label: A
options.text: A second physician may be more likely to diagnose a patient accurately if they are aware of the first physician's diagnosis.

options.label: B
options.text: A second physician may be less likely to diagnose a patient accurately if they are aware of the first physician's diagnosis.

options.label: C
options.text: A patient may be more likely to seek a second opinion if they disagree with the first physician's diagnosis.

options.label: D
options.text: A patient may be less likely to seek a second opinion if they agree with the first physician's diagnosis.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the transcript regarding human memory?

options.label: A
options.text: Human memory is a reliable and accurate representation of reality.

options.label: B
options.text: Human memory is a subjective perception that can be influenced by various factors.

options.label: C
options.text: Human memory is only reliable for traumatic events.

options.label: D
options.text: Human memory is only reliable for recent events.
